results.title: Manon
results.brief_description:
After the Liberation, a former Resistance fighter rescues manon, a collaborator, from the avenging villagers. They flee to Paris where drives her lover to jealous rage by her involvement with profiteering and prostitution but, when he commits murder, she leaves France with him. Like Sacha Guitry, Clouzot was embittered by his treatment at the hands of the nation’s liberators, and like Guitry he gave his own, oblique response to them in a film. In ‘Manon’ he transformed the Abbe Prevost’s celebrated eighteenth century young lovers into lumpen refugees from a chaotic France in the midst of lawless ‘liberation’. ‘Manon’ is arguably one of Clouzot’s least convincing and well-formed films, but it is also one of his most personal, deeply felt works, dripping with contempt for what the director saw as his critics’ hypocritical refusal to admit the evils of the ocupation years had not ceased when France was ‘free’, because corruption has its roots in human nature itself and not in the actions of particular individuals.” Reference: Alan Williams. Republic of images: a history of French filmmaking. Harvard University Press, 1992. Awards: Golden Lion Venice Film Festival (Mostra) 1949.

Credits: Producer, P. E. Decharme ; director, Henri-Georges Clouzot ; writers, Henri-Georges Clouzot, Jean Ferry ; photography, Armand Thirard ; music, Paul Misraki ; art direction, Max Douy.
Cast: Cecile Aubry, Michel Auclair, Serge Reggiani, Gabrielle Dorziat, Raymond Souplex, Simone Valere, Dora Doll, Rosy Varte, Michel Bouquet, Robert Dalban, actors from the Lancey Yiddish Theatre.

results.title: Les Honneurs de la Guerre = the Honours of War
results.brief_description:
Nanteuil, 1944. The joy of the impending liberation is stopped by the arrival of a group of German soldiers. They have no murderous intent, in spite of the exhortations of one of their officers. They just want to make a deal: they will lock the population in the church and wait for the arrival of the US army to whom they want to surrender without fighting. During the wait in the church, the tension between the villagers rises, slowly entertained by a French fascist, to the point where bloodshed seems inevitable. For attempting to break the traditional image of the Resistance, this film was held on the shelves for two years and released only in February 1962

Credits: Producer, Daniel Muller ; director, Jean Dewever ; writer, Jean-Charles Tacchella ; photography, Ghislain Cloquet.
Cast: Pierre Collet, Paul Mercey, Henri Maik, Danielle Godet, Alix Mahieux, Bernard Verley.

results.title: Ballade Pour Un Voyou = Ballad for a Scoundrel
results.brief_description:
An ex-convict is recruited to deliver a suitcase whose contents are coveted by a variety of secret agents. When he runs off with the suitcase, the local police grab his girlfriend to ensure the safe delivery of the secret contents. The spies, police and free lance adventure seekers all go after the man and his coveted package. He must decide whether or not to blow up the contents when faced with a showdown with the authorities.

Credits: Producer, Jean Thuillier ; director, Jean-Claude Bonnardot ; writers, Jean-Claude Bonnardot, Jacqueline Sundstrom, Alexandre Tabor ; photography, Jean Badal ; music, Samson Francois.
Cast: Laurent Terzieff, Hildergarde Neff, Philippe Noiret, Michel Vitold, Daniel Emilfork, Etienne Bierry.

results.title: Des Enfants Gates = Spoiled Children
results.creator_credit: Michel Piccoli, WDR La Sept Cinema and Bertrand Tavernier
results.brief_description:
A famous director, unable to concentrate on his new script at home with his family, rents a flat in a high rise building. Instead of finding peace and quiet, he gets involved in the tenants’ fight against an exploitative landlord, and with a girl half his age.

Credits: Producers, Alain Sarde, Michel Piccoli, Bertrand Tavernier ; director, Bertrand Tavernier ; writers, Christine Pascal, Charlotte Dubreuil, Bertrand Tavernier ; photography, Alain Levent ; music, Philippe Sarde.
Cast: Michel Piccoli, Christine Pascal, Michel Aumont, Gerard Jugnot, Arlette Bonnard, Genevieve Mnich, Thierry Lhermitte, Michel Blanc, Daniel Toscan du Plantier, Martin Lamotte.

results.title: L'eau a la Bouche = to Each His Own
results.brief_description:
Milena lives with her grandmother in the Chateau d’Aubarede. At the death of the old woman, Milena invites two cousins, Seraphine and Jean-Paul, to attend the reading of the will. Seraphine arrives first accompanied by Robert, her lover, who decides to pass for Jean-Paul. Robert is fascinated with Milena and falls in love with her. As a means of revenge, Seraphine seduces young Miguel, the family lawyer. Then Jean-Paul arrives … The films contains several reference to classic films such as ‘La regle du jeu’ (Renoir, 1939) and ‘Smiles of a summer night’ (Bergman, 1958)

Credits: Producer, Pierre Braunberger ; director, Jacques Doniol-Valcroze ; writer, Jacques Doniol-Valcroze ; photography, Roger Fellous ; music, Serge Gainsbourg.
Cast: Bernadette Lafont, Michel Galabru, Alexandra Stewart, Francoise Brion, Gerard Barray, Paul Guers.

results.title: Le Plaisir = House of Pleasure
results.brief_description:
An adaptation of three ironic short stories by Guy de Maupassant ostensibly linked by a common theme: the paradoxical deceptions of pleasure. The first story, ‘Le Masque’, contrasts pleasure and old age in the story of an old man so addicted to dancing that he wears a mask to disguise his age. The second story, ‘Le Modele’, opposes pleasure and marriage. A young painter has an affair with his model, which after her attempted suicide ends with their marriage. The third, ‘La Maison Tellier’, is virtually a short feature. Pleasure and purity are opposed as the inmates of a city brothel spend a day in the country attending the first communion of the madame’s niece.

Credits: Director, Max Ophuls ; writers, Jacques Natanson ; photography, Christian Matras, Philippe Agostini ; music, Maurice Yvain, Joe Hajos ; art direction, Jean d’Eaubonne.
Cast: Danielle Darrieux, Jean Gabin, Jean Servais, Claude Dauphin, Gaby Morlay, Madeleine Renaud, Helena Manson, Daniel Gelin, Simone Simon, Pierre Brasseur, Anton Wallbrook, Henri Cremieux, Paulette Dubost, Ginette Leclerc, Mila Parely, Louis Seigner

results.title: L'enfance Nue = Nude Childhood
results.creator_credit: Maurice Pialat, Claude Berri, Francois Truffaut and Mag Bodard
results.brief_description:
Ten year old Francois, abandonned by his mother, is sent to a working-class foster family where his behaviour becomes rather disturbing. After several incidents, he is sent to an other family. The parents are elderly, the grandmother ancient and a foster brother awkward and shy. The placement proves a success, although it eventually leads to a crisis. After a decade in televison, Pialat made his directorial debut with a New Wave style drama of adolescence featuring a cast of non-professional players. Such films, ten years after the arrival of the ‘nouvelle vague’, had become a kind of recognized genre unto themselves rather than a striking gesture of independence from established norms, and it is not surprising that Pialat’s work often led him in other directions. Reference: Alan Williams. “Republic of images: a history of French filmmaking”. Harvard University Press, 1992. Awards: Prix Jean Vigo 1969.

Credits: Producers, Claude Berri, Mag Bodard, Francois Truffaut ; director, Maurice Pialat ; writers, Maurice Pialat, Arlette Langman ; photography, Claude Beausoleil.
Cast: Michel Tarrazon, Linda Gutemberg, Raoul Billerey, Pierrette Delplanque.

results.title: Les Coeurs Verts = the Green Hearts
results.brief_description:
Two young men, fresh out of prison for misdemeanor, attempt to stay on the straight and narrow. They often find themselves torn between family, mates and the necessity of finding a job. Filmed in the high-rise projects of Nanterre, this film is an uncompromising look at the life of young people eking a living at the edge of society. By its choice of topic and its stylistic, this film is at odds with the mainstream of the 1960s cinematographic production. Other artists and technicians credited: Maurice Dugowson, Serge Gainsbourg. See also: Les enfants du Palais [X000369] and Le petit Marcel [X000486].

Credits: Producer, Raoul Ploquin ; director, writer, Edouard Luntz ; photography, Jean Badal ; music, Jean-Louis Chautemps, Bernard Vitet, Guy Pedersen, Daniel Humair, Henri Renaud ; editors, Colette Kouchner, Suzanne Schiffman.
Cast: Gerard Zimmermann, Erick Penet, Maryse Maire, Paul Preboist, Francois Dyrek.

results.title: Le Passage du Rhin = Tomorrow Is My Turn
results.brief_description:
Roger, a baker, and Jean, a journalist, are both interned in a POW camp in Germany. They are given an opportuniy to escape when they are taken to work as farm hands on local properties. Jean tricks the farmer’s innocent daughter, Helga, into helping him escape. Roger, who has truly fallen for a local girl, decides to stay. But, soon after Jean’s escape, Helga falls under the suspicion of the local authorities. Award: Venice Film Festival 1960: Golden Lion.

Credits: Director, Andre Cayatte ; writers, Andre Cayatte, Armand Jammot, Maurice Auberge, Pascal Jardin ; photography, Roger Fellous ; music, Louiguy.
Cast: Nicole Courcel, Charles Aznavour, Cordula Trantow, Georges Riviere, Betty Schneider, Georges Chamarat, Colette Regis, Alfred Schieske, Ruth Hansmeister, Jean Marchat.

results.title: Histoire D'adrien = Story of Adrien
results.brief_description:
Adrien, an illegitimate child, must endure the nastiness of those around him. Only his grandmother gives him love and understanding. After her death, the young boy finds a job as a flour-mill worker. Adrien witnesses the changes in country life as machines take on the jobs of several men. Adrien grows up and becomes a railway worker and falls in love with a laundress, Marguerite. But her parents to do not look favourably on their daughter marrying a poor man. In order to evoke the memory of country life in the South of France at the turn of the 20th Century, Jean-Pierre Denis delved into the collective memory of actors and locals who spoke exclusively in Occitan. This gave a great authenticity to the depiction (or painting, as certain scenes are filmed to resemble works by Georges de la Tour) of rural life and contributed to ascertain that an original, local culture had survived successive waves of modernisation and mechanisation. In parallel, the film shows the first sketches of an other world: the world of factory workers with its struggles, strikes and energy. Awards: Cannes Film Festival 1980: Camera D’Or for Debut Feature Film.

Credits: Director, Jean-Pierre Denis ; writers, Francoise Dudognon, Jean-Pierre Denis ; photography, Denis Gheerbrant ; music, Joan Pao Verdier.
Cast: Bertrand Sautereau, Serge Dominique, Pierre Dieuaide, Marcelle Dessales, Odette Peytoureau.

Adrien, an illegitimate child, must endure the nastiness of those around him. Only his grandmother gives him love and understanding. After her death, the young boy finds a job as a flour-mill worker. Adrien witnesses the changes in country life as machines take on the jobs of several men. Adrien grows up and becomes a railway worker and falls in love with a laundress, Marguerite. But her parents to do not look favourably on their daughter marrying a poor man. In order to evoke the memory of country life in the South of France at the turn of the 20th Century, Jean-Pierre Denis delved into the collective memory of actors and locals who spoke exclusively in Occitan. This gave a great authenticity to the depiction (or painting, as certain scenes are filmed to resemble works by Georges de la Tour) of rural life and contributed to ascertain that an original, local culture had survived successive waves of modernisation and mechanisation. In parallel, the film shows the first sketches of an other world: the world of factory workers with its struggles, strikes and energy. Awards: Cannes Film Festival 1980: Camera D’Or for Debut Feature Film.

Credits: Director, Jean-Pierre Denis ; writers, Francoise Dudognon, Jean-Pierre Denis ; photography, Denis Gheerbrant ; music, Joan Pao Verdier.
Cast: Bertrand Sautereau, Serge Dominique, Pierre Dieuaide, Marcelle Dessales, Odette Peytoureau.
